headline: Lagos has special status: Let’s make it official
summarized_story:
I imagine any of you, dear compatriots, somewhere in Paris or Hague, at an International Conference, listening to a speaker presenting city profiles as he latched onto Lagos: Lagos State’s GDP is bigger than the rest of West Africa put together; if Lagos is a country, it would be the 5th largest economy in Africa.
Nigerian leaders today –the Senate- can revisit this promise and start somewhere, where the need is greatest, by recognising and providing for Lagos’ Special Status.
Let the derivable content of a special status for Lagos State change from “special favours” as presently perceived to that of fair share of stakes and opportunities.
Recognise and confirm Lagos State’s special status and let the attendant benefit revamp Lagos, speed it to becoming the major African hub of progress, commerce and development that the biggest city in Nigeria ought to be.
Setonji , Chairman, House Committee on Information, Strategy, & Security, Lagos State House of Assembly, wrote from LagosVanguard News Nigeria

headline: Rep member, Akande-Sadipe seeks Justice for hit-and-run accident victim
summarized_story:

headline: CBN to introduce digital currency in Nigeria
summarized_story:
The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) has revealed plans to introduce digital currency before the end of 2021.
Speaking at the end of the 306th Bankers’ Committee Meeting in Lagos, Mohammed said the currency would be accessible to all Nigerians.
“The CBN is exploring the possibility of issuing digital currency.

headline: June 12: Police warn against protest in Delta
summarized_story:
The Delta State Police Command led by CP Ari Muhammad Ali has said it will not allow miscreants to disturb the peace of the state, warning residents against any planned protests in the State on June 12.
The police chief handed down the warning in a statement signed by the Acting Police Public Relations Officer, DSP Bright Edafe.
Ali noted that the protest is being staged by criminally minded individuals hiding under the guise of peaceful protest thereby causing havoc in the State.
“Members of the public, particularly residents of Delta State are to be aware that on no account should any group be seen, gathering or carrying placards in the name of protest, as such will not be allowed in the state.
“The command is committed to maintain and sustain the peace the state is currently enjoying,” the statement read.

headline: Nigeria’s Central Bank to launch digital currency before 2022
summarized_story:
Nigeria may pilot an official digital currency in 2021, going by the words of Rakiyat Mohammed, a Central Bank Director in charge of the Information Technology Department, who revealed on Thursday that the banking regulator will soon launch a digital currency.
A Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) represents a country’s official currency in digital form.
According to the CBN director, about 80% of central banks in the world are currently exploring the possibility of issuing central bank digital currency and Nigeria could not be left behind.
Last year, the Bahamas launched the world’s first central bank digital currency.
When it eventually becomes operational, the digital currency will complement the existing forms of currency in the country and could help reduce the high cost of managing and transferring cash.

headline: Malami reverses self, says Twitter users will no longer be prosecuted
summarized_story:

headline: Obasanjo, Ooni, Other Leaders Meet In Abuja
summarized_story:
Former President Olusegun Obasanjo on Thursday met with various leaders including the Ooni of Ife, Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi, the Sultan of Sokoto, his eminence Sa’ad Abubakar, and former Head of State, General Abdulsalami Abubakar, as part of efforts to address the myriad of challenges bedevilling the country.
The closed-door meeting which lasted for over nine hours took place at the Kano Conference Hall of the Transcorp Hilton Hotel, Abuja.
However, at the end of the meeting, former President Obasanjo could not be sighted for comments, while former Head of State, General Abdulsalami declined to speak to journalists.
Meanwhile, the former Minister of Agriculture, Audu Ogbe and Cardinal John Onaiyekan who were also present, simply told journalists that the meeting was for the progress of the country.
Ogbe said a communique on the outcome of the meeting will be issued soon.

headline: COVID-19: Pakistan Province To Block Mobile Phones Of Unvaccinated People
summarized_story:
A Pakistan province said Friday it will block the mobile phones of people refusing to get Covid-19 jabs, in the latest move to penalise the unvaccinated in a country where only a fraction of the population have been inoculated.
It comes after Sindh province said civil servants who refuse to be vaccinated will not be paid from July.
A third wave of infections has begun to stabilise in Pakistan after weeks of tough restrictions, and in Punjab — the country’s most populous province which includes the megacity of Lahore — demand for jabs has slowed.
Mobile vaccine centres will also be set up outside shrines to reach people in rural areas.
National data also shows that around 300,000 recipients of the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine haven’t returned for a second dose.

headline: NANS suspends planned June 12 nationwide protest over fears of hijack
summarized_story:
The National Association of Nigerian Students has suspended its planned June 12 nationwide protest.
The Statement titled, ‘NANS Suspends June 12 Protest Over Concerns About Safety Of Protesters And Fear Of Possible Hijack By Politicians – Comrade Sunday Asefon’.
According to Asefon, the planned protest was aimed at decrying the insecurity in the country, especially the serial abductions of students.
Asefon said some politicians with a “different agenda” have perfected plans to hijack the protest to “ventilate their political opinions and sentiments”.
He said, “Having considered the current security realities and the danger to the lives of our members in case of possible hijack of the planned protest, I in consultation with all the structures of NANS, therefore, announce the suspension of our proposed protest for June 12.

headline: Twitter Ban: Nigeria Government Accounts Migrate to Indian Microblogging Platform Koo
summarized_story:
The suspension of Twitter by the Nigerian government has forced the federal government and some agencies of government to move to Koo, an Indian microblogging platform, to keep in touch with the public.
Barely a week after banning the tech giant over the deletion of a tweet on President Muhammadu Buhari’s account, the federal government has joined the Indian microblogging site.
It has already opened an official account on the platform with the handle @nigeriagov and had above 10,000 followers as at Thursday night.
Koo co-Founder Aprameya Radhakrishna, who confirmed that the platform is now available in Nigeria, said they are working on adding Nigeria’s local languages.
